article:
'In situhybridization (ISH)' is a type of hybridization that uses a labeled
complementary DNA or RNA strand (i.e., probe) to localize a specific DNA or RNA
sequence in a portion or section of tissue ([[in situ]]), or, if the tissue is
small enough (e.g. plant seeds, [[Drosophila]] embryos), in the entire tissue
(whole mount ISH), in cells and in circulating tumor cells (CTCs). This is
distinct from immunohistochemistry, which usually localizes proteins in tissue
sections. DNA ISH can be used to determine the structure of chromosomes.
Fluorescent DNA ISH (FISH) can, for example, be used in medical diagnostics to
assess chromosomal integrity. RNA ISH (RNA in situ hybridization) is used to
measure and localize RNAs (mRNAs, lncRNAs and miRNAs) within tissue sections,
cells, whole mounts, and circulating tumor cells (CTCs). In situ hybridization
was invented by Joseph G. Gall.
